annotator_prompt:
You are a human working as an annotator Your name is annotator. Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: Dutifully follow the following instructions, personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. 
You are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.
The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

Your output must be of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do not write anything else. 

Example:
User DarkShadow333 posted:   @TechGuru88, you're just another
snowflake trying to muzzle free speech. I don't need to present my
arguments with kid gloves. If you can't handle the heat, stay out of
the kitchen. And @moderator, who made you the thought police? This is
a free country, and I'll say what I want. If you don't like it, maybe
you should find a safe space where you can hide from the big bad
words. 😈💥

Output: Toxicity=4

Annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.
Toxicity=3

Oh, @FirstUser, you're just full of sunshine and rainbows, aren't you? Last time I checked, Jesus was all about loving thy neighbor, even if they were born on the other side of a man-made border. But hey, why let a little thing like compassion get in the way of your fear-mongering, right? And while we're at it, how about we talk about the number of murders committed by white supremacists in the US this year? Or are we only concerned with statistics when they fit your narrative?
Toxicity=3

@FirstUser, you're right, the Bible doesn't mention immigration rights, but it does say a lot about loving thy neighbor and welcoming the stranger. Seems like we're supposed to be more concerned with the content of someone's character than the color of their passport. And @QueenOfChaos, you're spot on. Let's not forget that fear-mongering and hate have no place in a society that claims to be built on Christian values. We should be looking at the root causes of crime, not just scapegoating immigrants. Let's have a real conversation about this, not just throw statistics around to suit our agendas.
Toxicity=2

@FirstUser, you're right that the Bible doesn't explicitly mention immigration rights, but it does emphasize hospitality and caring for the stranger. Leviticus 19:34 says, The foreigner residing among you must be treated as your native-born. Love them as yourself, for you were foreigners in Egypt. It's not about statistics or fear-mongering, but about compassion and understanding. Let's not forget that many of these 'illegal aliens' are seeking a better life, just like our ancestors did. @QueenOfChaos, you raise a valid point about white supremacist violence, but let's not counter hate with hate. We should address all forms of violence and discrimination, not just the ones that fit our narrative. Let's strive for a more compassionate and understanding society, regardless of our political leanings.
Toxicity=1

@WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. It's about compassion and understanding, not statistics or fear. And you're right, many of these folks are just seeking a better life, just like our ancestors did. It's a shame that some people can't see that. But hey, @FirstUser, if you're so concerned about crime, why don't we talk about the real issues? Like the fact that the majority of undocumented immigrants are actually law-abiding people just trying to make a living. Or the fact that studies have shown that areas with higher immigration rates actually have lower crime rates. But nah, let's just keep throwing out baseless claims and scapegoating immigrants, right? That'll solve all our problems.
Toxicity=1

@GoldenYears66, you're preaching to the choir here. It's frustrating when people cherry-pick statistics to fit their agenda, isn't it? But let's not get too discouraged. We know the truth, and we can keep spreading compassion and understanding, one conversation at a time. As for @FirstUser, maybe they just need more time to see the light. After all, change often comes slowly. Let's just keep the dialogue open and respectful, even when it's challenging. That's the only way we can hope to make a difference.
Toxicity=1

@WiseOwl71, you're right, we can't give up. But sometimes, it feels like we're talking to a brick wall with some of these folks. Take @FirstUser, for instance. They're so busy throwing out baseless claims and fear-mongering, they can't even see the real issues right in front of them. It's like they're wearing blinders, only seeing what they want to see. And don't even get me started on their selective memory when it comes to our own history. They act like our ancestors didn't come here seeking a better life too. It's enough to make you want to bang your head against a wall. But you're right, we can't let it get to us. We just gotta keep on keeping on, spreading the truth and hoping that eventually, it'll sink in.
Toxicity=1

@GoldenYears66, I feel your frustration, truly. It can be disheartening when people refuse to see the facts right in front of them. But remember, change often comes from the most unexpected places. Sometimes, all it takes is one person to challenge their beliefs and open their mind. And who knows, maybe @FirstUser will be that one person. We can't force them to see the light, but we can certainly keep the light shining brightly. Let's not let their stubbornness discourage us. Instead, let's use it as fuel to keep pushing forward. After all, the only way to combat ignorance is with knowledge and understanding. So, let's keep the dialogue going, no matter how challenging it may be.
Toxicity=1

@GoldenYears66, @WiseOwl71, you two are just a bundle of sunshine and rainbows, aren't you? Always ready to pat each other on the back and sing kumbaya. But let me ask you this, how's that compassion and understanding working out for you so far? Because last time I checked, the world is still a mess, and people are still suffering. Maybe it's time to try something new, like, I don't know, actually addressing the real problems instead of just feeling good about yourselves. But hey, what do I know? I'm just a bitter, old troll.
Toxicity=3

@QueenOfChaos, your cynicism is noted, but I'm not sure it's productive. Yes, the world has its problems, but dismissing compassion and understanding as ineffective is shortsighted. Change takes time, and it often starts with small steps. We can't just snap our fingers and fix everything overnight. But by fostering open dialogue and empathy, we're planting seeds that can grow into something meaningful. As for feeling good about ourselves, I'd argue that's a byproduct of trying to make a difference, not the goal. So, let's not throw the baby out with the bathwater. We can address real problems and maintain compassion. It's not an either/or situation.
Toxicity=2

@QueenOfChaos, you're right, the world is a mess, and it's easy to get discouraged. But I've seen enough in my 66 years to know that change doesn't happen overnight. It's a slow, often painful process. And yeah, sometimes it feels like we're just spinning our wheels. But I'd rather be trying to make a difference, even if it's just a little bit, than throwing my hands up and giving up. As for your comment about feeling good about ourselves, I'm not sure that's what we're doing. I know I don't feel good about the state of the world. But I do feel good about the fact that I'm trying to do something about it. And if that makes me a sunshine and rainbows kind of guy, then so be it. Because at least I'm not sitting on the sidelines, doing nothing.
Toxicity=1

@GoldenYears66, well said. It's easy to get bogged down by the enormity of the problems we face, but as you pointed out, change is a marathon, not a sprint. And @QueenOfChaos, while your skepticism might be warranted, it's also important to remember that progress isn't always linear. Sometimes, it's two steps forward, one step back. But that doesn't mean we should stop moving forward. As for feeling good about ourselves, I think it's a natural byproduct of doing what we believe is right. It's not about patting ourselves on the back, but rather, finding a sense of purpose and fulfillment in our actions. So, let's keep pushing forward, one step at a time.
Toxicity=1

@WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. It's about the journey, not the destination. And @QueenOfChaos, I understand your frustration, I really do. But dismissing the efforts of those who are trying to make a difference isn't going to get us anywhere. It's like you're standing at the edge of a cliff, looking down at the valley below, and saying, Well, we're not at the top of the mountain yet, so what's the point? The point is, we're climbing. We're making progress, even if it's slow. And yeah, sometimes we slip and fall back a bit, but that doesn't mean we stop climbing. So, let's keep moving forward, one step at a time. And if you want to join us, @QueenOfChaos, we'd be happy to have you. But if you'd rather stand at the edge and criticize, that's your choice. Just don't be surprised when the view doesn't change.
Toxicity=1

@GoldenYears66, you've hit the nail on the head. It's all about the journey and the effort we put in. @QueenOfChaos, your cynicism is understandable, but it's also a choice. You can choose to stand on the sidelines and criticize, or you can choose to join us and make a difference, no matter how small. And yes, sometimes it feels like we're not making any progress, but that's when we need to look back and see how far we've come. Change isn't always visible in the moment, but it's there, slowly but surely. So, let's not get discouraged by the distance left to travel, but rather, let's celebrate the ground we've already covered. And who knows, maybe one day, @QueenOfChaos, you'll look back and realize
Toxicity=1

@WiseOwl71, you're preaching to the choir here. I've seen enough in my lifetime to know that change takes time and effort. But it's the effort that counts, not the immediate results. And @QueenOfChaos, if you're waiting for some grand, overnight transformation, you're going to be waiting a long time. The world doesn't work that way. It's the small steps, the daily grind, that add up to real change. So, if you're tired of waiting for something big to happen, why not join us and make something small happen? Because that's how we climb mountains, one step at a time. And if you're still not convinced, well, that's
Toxicity=1
